Question: Jupiter's orbital distance is roughly 5 AU. How many times brighter would the Sun have to be for Europa to receive the same solar flux that we currently receive on Earth (1380W/m2)?
Choices:
A. 100 times brighter
B. 25 times brighter
C. 2 times brighter
D. 50 times brighter
Answer:
100 times brighter

D. 50 times brighter
Answer:
25 times brighter

Question: From shortest to longest wavelength which of the following correctly orders the different categories of electromagnetic radiation?
Choices:
A. infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays radio
B. radio infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays
C. gamma rays X rays visible light ultraviolet infrared radio
D. gamma rays X rays ultraviolet visible light infrared radio
Answer:
infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays radio

Question: From shortest to longest wavelength which of the following correctly orders the different categories of electromagnetic radiation?
Choices:
A. infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays radio
B. radio infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays
C. gamma rays X rays visible light ultraviolet infrared radio
D. gamma rays X rays ultraviolet visible light infrared radio
Answer:
radio infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays

Question: From shortest to longest wavelength which of the following correctly orders the different categories of electromagnetic radiation?
Choices:
A. infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays radio
B. radio infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays
C. gamma rays X rays visible light ultraviolet infrared radio
D. gamma rays X rays ultraviolet visible light infrared radio
Answer:
gamma rays X rays visible light ultraviolet infrared radio

Question: From shortest to longest wavelength which of the following correctly orders the different categories of electromagnetic radiation?
Choices:
A. infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays radio
B. radio infrared visible light ultraviolet X rays gamma rays
C. gamma rays X rays visible light ultraviolet infrared radio
D. gamma rays X rays ultraviolet visible light infrared radio
Answer:
gamma rays X rays ultraviolet visible light infrared radio

Question: The so-called “bigfoot” on Mars was actually a rock that was about 5 cm tall. It had an angular size of about 0.5 degrees (~30 pixels). How far away was this rock from the rover?
Choices:
A. About 6 meters
B. About 6 feet
C. About 10 meters
D. About 10 feet
Answer:
About 6 meters

About 6 feet

Question: Which of the following methods has led to the most discoveries of massive planets orbiting near their parent stars?
Choices:
A. detecting the gravitational effect of an orbiting planet by looking for the Doppler shifts in the star's spectrum
B. detecting the shift of the star's position against the sky due to the planet's gravitational pull
C. detecting a planet ejected from a binary star system
D. detecting the starlight reflected off the planet
Answer:
detecting the gravitational effect of an orbiting planet by looking for the Doppler shifts in the star's spectrum

Question: Which of the following methods has led to the most discoveries of massive planets orbiting near their parent stars?
Choices:
A. detecting the gravitational effect of an orbiting planet by looking for the Doppler shifts in the star's spectrum
B. detecting the shift of the star's position against the sky due to the planet's gravitational pull
C. detecting a planet ejected from a binary star system
D. detecting the starlight reflected off the planet
Answer:
detecting the shift of the star's position against the sky due to the planet's gravitational pull

Question: Which of the following methods has led to the most discoveries of massive planets orbiting near their parent stars?
Choices:
A. detecting the gravitational effect of an orbiting planet by looking for the Doppler shifts in the star's spectrum
B. detecting the shift of the star's position against the sky due to the planet's gravitational pull
C. detecting a planet ejected from a binary star system
D. detecting the starlight reflected off the planet
Answer:
detecting a planet ejected from a binary star system

Question: Which of the following methods has led to the most discoveries of massive planets orbiting near their parent stars?

B. detecting the shift of the star's position against the sky due to the planet's gravitational pull
C. detecting a planet ejected from a binary star system
D. detecting the starlight reflected off the planet
Answer:
detecting the starlight reflected off the planet

Question: Approximately how far away is the Andromeda Galaxy?
Choices:
A. 1.7 million light years

Answer:

Question: How do scientists know that the majority of meteorites come from the asteroid belt?
Choices:
A. Bubbles of gas trapped in the crystals within meteorites are identical to the gases trapped in asteroids.
B. The spectra of some meteorites are similar to the spectra of asteroids in the asteroid belt.
C. Collisions are common in the asteroid belt and we can track the fragments from their source asteroid to the Earth where they become meteorites.
D. The asteroid belt is the only possible source of meteorites therefore they must originate there.
Answer:
Bubbles of gas trapped in the crystals within meteorites are identical to the gases trapped in asteroids.

Question: How do scientists know that the majority of meteorites come from the asteroid belt?
Choices:
A. Bubbles of gas trapped in the crystals within meteorites are identical to the gases trapped in asteroids.

D. The asteroid belt is the only possible source of meteorites therefore they must originate there.
Answer:
The spectra of some meteorites are similar to the spectra of asteroids in the asteroid belt.

Question: Which of the following is/are common feature(s) of all fresh (i.e. not eroded) impact craters formed on solid surfaces:
Choices:
A. ejecta
B. raised rims
C. central peaks
D. A and B only
Answer:
ejecta

Question: Which of the following is/are common feature(s) of all fresh (i.e. not eroded) impact craters formed on solid surfaces:
Choices:
A. ejecta
B. raised rims
C. central peaks
D. A and B only
Answer:
raised rims

Choices:
A. ejecta
B. raised rims
C. central peaks
D. A and B only
Answer:
central peaks

Choices:
A. ejecta
B. raised rims
C. central peaks
D. A and B only
Answer:
A and B only

Question: Why are the inner planets made of denser materials than the outer planets?
Choices:
A. In the beginning when the protoplanetary disk was spinning faster centrifugal forces flung the lighter materials toward the outer parts of the solar nebula.
B. In the inner part of the nebula only metals and rocks were able to condense because of the high temperatures whereas hydrogen compounds although more abundant were only able to condense in the cooler outer regions.
C. Denser materials were heavier and sank to the center of the nebula.
D. When the solar nebula formed a disk materials naturally segregated into bands and in our particular solar system the denser materials settled nearer the Sun while lighter materials are found in the outer part.
Answer:
In the beginning when the protoplanetary disk was spinning faster centrifugal forces flung the lighter materials toward the outer parts of the solar nebula.

Question: Pluto's extremely cold (~40 K) surface is composed of:
Choices:
A. mainly water ice which always remains frozen
B. nitrogen methane and carbon monoxide ices which sublimate into an atmosphere near perihelion
C. nitrogen methane and carbon monoxide ices which always remain frozen
D. roughly half ices and half rocky materials
Answer:
mainly water ice which always remains frozen

Question: Pluto's extremely cold (~40 K) surface is composed of:
Choices:
A. mainly water ice which always remains frozen
B. nitrogen methane and carbon monoxide ices which sublimate into an atmosphere near perihelion
C. nitrogen methane and carbon monoxide ices which always remain frozen
D. roughly half ices and half rocky materials
Answer:
nitrogen methane and carbon monoxide ices which sublimate into an atmosphere near perihelion

Question: Why did the solar nebula heat up as it collapsed?
Choices:
A. Collisions among planetesimals generated friction and heat.
B. Radiation from other nearby stars that had formed earlier heated the nebula.
C. The shock wave from a nearby supernova heated the gas.
D. As the cloud shrank its gravitational potential energy was converted to kinetic energy and then into thermal energy.
Answer:
Collisions among planetesimals generated friction and heat.

Question: Why did the solar nebula heat up as it collapsed?
Choices:
A. Collisions among planetesimals generated friction and heat.
B. Radiation from other nearby stars that had formed earlier heated the nebula.
C. The shock wave from a nearby supernova heated the gas.
D. As the cloud shrank its gravitational potential energy was converted to kinetic energy and then into thermal energy.
Answer:
Radiation from other nearby stars that had formed earlier heated the nebula.
